title: 106_hr4866
content: The Act may be cited as the "Debt Relief Reconciliation Act for Fiscal Year 2001" and includes findings and purpose. The Congress finds that fiscal discipline and economic growth have led to budget surpluses, but future fiscal pressures will increase due to an aging population. It is recommended to use the social security surplus to reduce public debt, which will promote economic growth and prepare for future budget obligations. The purpose of this Act is to reduce public debt by using a portion of the nonsocial security surplus and decrease the statutory limit on public debt by 2013. Establishment of Public Debt Reduction Payment Account. The Public Debt Reduction Payment Account is established in the Treasury of the United States to pay, redeem, or buy government obligations held by the public, with the obligation being canceled and retired. Amounts in the account are appropriated for this purpose. The Public Debt Reduction Payment Account is established in the Treasury of the United States with $25,000,000,000 appropriated for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2001. The funds will remain available until expended and are not considered direct spending. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will ensure prompt implementation in accordance with debt management policies. The Public Debt Reduction Payment Account is established with $25,000,000,000 appropriated for fiscal year 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will ensure prompt implementation in accordance with debt management policies. A conforming amendment is made to the chapter analysis for chapter 31 of title 31, United States Code. The Public Debt Reduction Payment Account is established with $25,000,000,000 appropriated for fiscal year 2001. Section 3101(b) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to reduce the statutory limit on public debt by the amount appropriated into the account. The account's receipts and disbursements are not counted as new budget authority, outlays, receipts, or deficit for budget purposes. SEC. 6. Removing Public Debt Reduction Payment Account from budget pronouncements. The Public Debt Reduction Payment Account is excluded from budget statements and reports to Congress, with its outlays and receipts submitted separately in budget documents. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress within 30 days of depositing funds into the Public Debt Reduction Payment Account, detailing the amount and date of deposit, as well as plans to reduce public debt. Another report must be submitted by October 31, 2002, outlining the deposited amount and public debt reduction progress. The Secretary of the Treasury must report to Congress on the funds deposited into the Payment Account and plans to reduce public debt. The Comptroller General of the United States will verify this information by November 15, 2002. The Payment Account funds report must be verified by the Comptroller General of the United States by November 15, 2002. Passed by the House of Representatives on July 18, 2000.
